title: How to Muck Out a Stall

steps.headline: Remove the hay, water bucket and manger to avoid contamination and keep the stall clean.
steps.description: Removing the horse is also a good idea.

steps.headline: Remove all the bigger, more obvious droppings on the surface with the shavings fork or rubber glove.
steps.description: Sift the shavings through the pitchfork so all that remains is manure(droppings). Then, deposit the manure in the wheelbarrow.

steps.headline: Toss the shavings to the sides of the stall next.
steps.description: Remove any droppings that fall out of them as you do so.

steps.headline: Scoop up the wet shavings with the shavings fork.
Sweep the floor and shovel up any remaining manure.
Leave the floor to dry and air out for a while.
steps.description: Then you can pull back the shavings to lay the bed. Bank up the shavings against the walls.

steps.headline: Add new shavings, if necessary.
steps.description: To open the bale, cut the tape with scissors or a special safety barn knife that has a recessed blade.

steps.headline: Use the four-pronged pitchfork to loosen them and dump them into the stall.
Spread the shavings around to make a comfortable stall.
Replace the water and feed bowls.
steps.description: If you couldn’t remove the water bowl because it was fixed to the wall, change the water.

steps.headline: Sweep the yard if necessary and put the tools back neatly.
steps.description: This is especially important if you are boarding your horse.

tyn: Rubber Boots or comfortable work boots
